sub_title: Psychologist: clinical, neuro, community and research.
summary:
Thank you for visiting my LinkedIn profile.  My partner, Braam Hoffmann and I started our new adventure in The Netherlands on the 1st January 2019.

I had just completed an exciting project in the Correctional Services in South Africa.  Together with the community - a bio-ethicist, prosecutor and academic philosophers - a group of incarcerated people have been trying to make sense of re-igniting Ubuntu in their society:  Umuntu ngumuntu ngabantu / I am because we are / A person is a person through others.     

My 25 years of practice in South Africa and the UK, taught me that Ubuntu informs the essence of what I do, especially working with individuals and families who are living with neurological and psychiatric symptoms or people who have been convicted.  

The interconnectedness of life fascinates me: from the neurons in the brain to our social world.  I am excited to assist positive change in people's lives utilizing this interplay: whether it is micro-changes having macro effects or vice versa. Because we are inter-dependent, what happens to an individual affects everyone who forms part of their world.  I believe that feeling integrated, having an individual purpose and experiencing a sense of community and belonging is important to our well-being and crucial to our development.   

My work has mostly been as part of multi-disciplinary teams as a co-traveller in people's journeys of adjustment and recovery.  

Being new to The Netherlands, I am open to changes and looking for opportunities. I have been improving my Dutch language competency by volunteering at a mental health day centre, doing specialized courses and working as a group assistant on an elderly rehabilitation ward - Afrikaans and English are my home languages.   My broad provides me a lot of flexibility.  

Thanks to PsyNed - Psychologist Eindhoven - Mindfull sollutions is the platform from which I provide my services as a Psycholoog NIP to the expat community.
  
Keywords - Clinical Psychology / Cognitive Deficits / Cognitive Rehabilitation / Cognitive Remediation / Cognitive Strategies / Brain Working Recursive Therapy/ Trauma Counselling / Cognitive Remediation Therapy / Community Psychology / Lecturing / Multi-disciplinary Teams / Neuropsychology / Research / Risk Assessment / Risk Management / Supervision /  Training / Vulnerability

profile_positions.description: Brain Working Recursive Therapy® is a modern therapy which has been demonstrated to provide effective results with symptoms of anxiety, grief and trauma. It is now also being used for other psychological difficulties such as depression and addiction. It integrates the knowledge from neuropsychological processing and psychotherapy in a way which is can be easily understood by service users.  The intervention can be applied in a short term and provides clear results for clients.  I have started specialising in this mode of therapy because of its relative quick and effective results, that it relies less on language than traditional therapies and translates so well online.  During corona time it seemed suitable to also add BWRT Neuroenhancement Practitioner® for those people who needed to get the most out of their physical exercises.
profile_positions.title: Psycholoog NIP, ZZP; BWRT® Levels 1&2; BWRT NET®

profile_positions.description: Whilst completing the PhD and managing the online practise I continued to do various posts to practise Dutch. This includes voluntary work for De Boei GGZ (2019-current), Groepsassistent for Oktober (2021-current), studying and working as a research assistant for Autisme Gehechtheid Loekemeijermethode (2019-current).  I am applying for psychological work which I can do in Englishg in the Netherlands.  Currently learning Dutch B1+.  B2 will be reached by the end of 2022.
profile_positions.title: Open for work ongoing - Psychologist: clinical, neuro, community, training and research

profile_positions.description:
The thesis reports on the development, application and testing of a model for rehabilitation. The study attempted to integrate evidence-based principles from neuorpsychology, community psychology and criminology, in a holistic, continuous and multi-disciplinary project.
A Concurrent Transformative approach was used. This involved participatory action research (PAR), not only as a research method, but as key element of the model and as the intervention to be studied. 
Cell monitors were invited to participate in an action research project which included exemplary representatives from the community. The project spanned a year and a half. This included a five-month period of intense practising of executive functions and Ubuntu ethics education and eight months of weekly meetings focusing on the PAR process. 
A variety of qualitative methods and quantitative pre and post measurements were applied to explore the impact of the intervention.
Significant changes were found in participants’ reported abilities to relax and their executive performance. These findings can be attributed to the intervention combining mindfulness and ethics education with real-life opportunities for executive functioning practice. This is in line with Triune Ethics Theory, which postulates that ethical selves and communities emerge not from top-down moral education but from real-life experiences that shape brain systems.
The qualitative findings unpack: ‘products’ that emerged from the real-life project, PAR development in 8 processes, 5 levels of transformative community development, the application of an ethical reasoning model, ethics as a spontaneous outcome and the themes that mattered to participants.
From these findings a rehabilitation model was developed that draws on the experiences and insights of incarcerated participants.
The thesis concludes that sustainable change is possible if society is included with the incarcerated for  a reciprocal rehabilitation to occur.
profile_positions.title: PhD: PAR to integrate neuro, community, crim in rehab interventions

profile_positions.description:
Coordinated, developed and provided a clinical psychological service for a Correctional Centre.
Submitted commended risk assessment and management reports to the National Council of Correctional Services (NCCS) (for people with a life sentence) and the local Parole Board for consideration of parole release.
Developed rehabilitation strategies by utilizing community psychology, neuropsychology and systems theory approaches.
profile_positions.title: Clinical Psychologist
Clinical Psychologist with a Special Interest in Neuropsychological Rehabilitation in the Community

profile_positions.description:
This was always a split post:
(1) mental health
(2) physical care community rehabilitation teams (see below) and 
(3) a neurological rehabilitation inpatient unit (see below) 

Included:
(4) External neuropsychological supervisor - Headley Court Rehabilitation Unit, Military of Defense, UK (Contract 2009-2010)
(5) Lecturer - BSc (Hons) Psychosocial Interventions - European Institute of Health and Medical Services, University of Surrey, UK (Honorary Contract 2005 - 2007)

Across these services, I brought a neuropsychological and community psychology approach.
Assisted multi-disciplinary teams to systemically understand and manage the everyday implications of cognitive deficits associated with neurological and psychiatric symptoms. 

(1) My psychological services in mental health care developed as the NHS Trust evolved from Chichester Priority Care to Sussex Weald and Downs and then the Sussex Partnership NHS Foundation Trust.   

(1.1) Rehabilitation and Continuing Care Services (1998 - 2000):
- Clinical psychology service to a long-stay ward, adults with learning disabilities, and older adults to prepare for the re-provision of services in the community
- Worked in collaboration with staff to develop skills in psycho-social interventions

(1.2) Community Rehabilitation Team (2000-2007):
- Managed a caseload of people with severe cognitive difficulties and psychosis
- Provided workshops for service users, families and staff and supervising other psychologists in the neuropsychological understanding of psychosis

(1.3) Assertive Out Reach Team and Locality Facilitator (2007 - 2010)
- Facilitated team-formulation to inform interventions for service users who required assertive outreach  
- Participated in a Cognitive Remediation Therapy for Psychosis research project
- Developed a supervision model for psychologists in adult services to translate neuropsychological assessments into everyday life and clinical care
- Facilitated a Neuropsychological Peer Interest Group
profile_positions.title: Clinical Psychologist  - (Mental Health) Rehabilitation and Recovery

profile_positions.description:
- A clinical assessment and treatment service was provided to four community rehabilitation teams (CRT) working with individuals and family systems.  
- Clinical psychological interventions aimed to assist people to effectively manage the impact of loss and cognitive difficulties at the various stages of their journey of recovery.  
- An Acquired Brain Injury (ABI) Review Meeting was initiated to coordinate collaborate multi-agencies work.  Parallel ABI Support and Education Groups for carers and service users were developed with multi-agency involvement.  
- Monthly psychology sessions were conducted for a support group for people with multiple sclerosis with a severe physical disability.
profile_positions.title: (2) Clinical Psychologist - (Neurological and Physical Disability) Community Rehabilitation Teams

profile_positions.description:
- Provided clinical psychological service to a neuropsychological rehabilitation unit working with individuals, families, and multi-agencies.   
- Performed joined assessment, formulation, and treatment with an Occupational Therapy and Speach and Language Therapy colleagues.  
- A monthly multidisciplinary formulation meeting was developed to facilitate the staff to understand and manage challenging behavior.  
- Facilitated continuity of care support from inpatient to community services.
profile_positions.title: (3) Clinical Psychologist - Donald Wilson House Inpatient Unit, St Richards Hospital
